oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Birthplace Of Bluegrass
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Monroe, Bill, 1911-1996; Bluegrass music;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Two color window card (black and deep red on white) announcing the Historical Marker Ceremony at the birthplace of Bluegrass, the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee on September 29. Poster features a metal photoplate. Center box reads: ""In December 1945, Grand Ole Opry star Bill Monroe and his mandolin brought to the Ryman Auditorium stage a band that created a new American musical form. With the banjo style of Earl Scruggs and the guitar of Lester Flatt, the new musical genre became known as 'Bluegrass.' This ensemble, augmented by the fiddle of Chubby Wise and the Bass of Howard Watts (also known as Cedric Rainwater), became know as the 'original bluegrass band,' which became the prototype for groups that followed.""
